result.ToD: CENTRAL PARK -- SEPTEMBER AFTERNOON A COUPLE
result.heading: CENTRAL PARK -- SEPTEMBER AFTERNOON A COUPLE

direction.raw_text: . CENTRAL PARK -- SEPTEMBER AFTERNOON A COUPLE moves down a walkway, deep in subdued conversation. All around them trees explode with autumn color. Birds sing. Their path is dappled with leafy shadow. To their left, on the sunny meadow, TEENAGERS throw saucers and footballs, smoke cigarettes and joints, drink beer and soda, savoring the waning hours of summer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ON THE COUPLE He is WILLS KEANE, late 40's to early 50's, strikingly handsome, impeccably dressed, and supremely poised. At first glance he has the proud glow of a hedonist who in the war against time has been the undisputed victor. Only a closer look hints at the toll of battle. His shoulders strain under the weight of so much repetition. His eyes are touched by regret. The lines in his face reveal an emerging disenchantment not so much with the world as with himself. Walking at his side is a WOMAN, 30, attractive and bright. Her name is unimportant because so many have come before her and, if the past prevails, so many will come after. She listens intently, as Wills finishes speaking -- WILLS -- and I could have waited to tell you, but I wanted to leave no room for misunderstanding.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you certainly didn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ANOTHER CENTRAL PARK WALKWAY -- LATER Still talking quietly, they pass into a more secluded area of the park--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is amused by his confidence -- WOMAN Oh, really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs. Then he stops. He hears something. She stops. She hears it, too. It's a GIRL'S VOICE. He casually turns and looks, squinting into the sun. He takes a few steps and there, between trees, he sees TWO DOZEN PEOPLE sitting on the grass and on folding chairs -- most are middle-aged or older with a distinctly intellectual- bohemian look to them. Standing and addressing them is CHARLOTTE FIELDING, 19, fair, willowy, pale, lovely in an unconventional way. She wears an eccentric hat and a vintage dress. Her bearing is upright, her gaze warm and intelligent, her voice rich with emotion -- CHARLOTTE -- and for weeks I sat by her bed and cried. I told her I loved her and I begged her not to leave me. All I could think about was what I'd lose if she died. And then one night... she was in really bad pain... I stopped thinking about myself for a second and I thought about her. (fighting tears) I stopped crying. I said goodbye. And in less than an hour Ella was gone. The woman whispers in Wills' ear -- WOMAN It's so sad. But Wills ignores her. He watches Charlotte with keen interest, touched by the depth and sincerity of her emotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks out at the group, many of whom are crying. A tear runs down her cheek. She smiles and wipes it away. The woman, seeing Wills' interest in the girl, whispers -- WOMAN So what do you know about her? He knows a great deal. Or at least he thinks he does. But his answer is nonchalant -- WILLS That she's just a kid. He takes the woman gently by the elbow and guides her away. He steals one last look back. Charlotte, returning to where she was sitting, notices Wills. Their eyes meet and a charge passes between them. Meanwhile an OLD MAN has risen from his chair -- OLD MAN I met Ella at City College in 1938... Wills slowly turns and walks away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, I see how you could feel this way. Of course I do. It's human. But what I don't get is why you'd want to announce it so quickly. I mean, we just met. Feelings change. You don't even know me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The minute I laid eyes on you. It's the saddest thing about getting older. You know people so quickly. I even knew you'd end up hating me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you're wrong. I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a weary smile) Give it time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I really think it's possible to hold a person back... cry them back... from dying. That's what I did to Ella and I'll never do it to anyone else again. (softly) I hope no one ever does it to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ascends the steps to the bustling street.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: MANHATTAN SUBWAY STOP -- AUTUMN DUSK A SWARM OF PEDESTRIANS

direction.raw_text: amid the swarm, struggling with a load of BOXES and SHOPPING BAGS, carrying an antique, wood-and-wire DRESSMAKER'S MANNEQUIN. She wears a peasant dress with a cycle jacket, a backpack, and another eccentric hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WASHINGTON SQUARE PARK -- DUSK Charlotte makes her way down the leaf-strewn pathway. Wheeling the mannequin by the neck, she passes NYU STUDENTS smoking, laughing, and chatting on their way to class.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WEST VILLAGE AVENUE -- DUSK Charlotte hauls the mannequin down the block. A YOUNG MAN offers her assistance, but she politely and firmly refuses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WEST VILLAGE STREET -- DUSK Charlotte wearily hauls the mannequin across the cobblestone street, over the curb, and up to the stoop of a charming but slightly dilapidated BROWNSTONE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BROWNSTONE FOYER -- DUSK Charlotte opens the door into the darkness. She hits a light switch and nothing happens. She flips it back and forth -- CHARLOTTE Shit. She dumps her boxes and bags, then wheels in the mannequin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dolly! The bulb burned out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: are crouched in the dark room. The mantel is draped with a HAPPY BIRTHDAY BANNER. The coffee table is stacked with WRAPPED GIFTS.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: BROWNSTONE LIVING ROOM -- SAME EIGHT SILHOUETTES

direction.raw_text: Charlotte looks suspiciously at the living room door -- CHARLOTTE Dolly? She tiptoes through the darkness and lays her ear against it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear chuckles and whispers of anticipation. An older woman's raspy, boozy voice growls -- RASPY VOICE My ass hurts. A few people chuckle, but they're quickly hushed. The DOOR KNOB TURNS and the DOOR OPENS. Everyone leaps up in a blaze of light -- ALL SURPRISE! The MANNEQUIN bursts into the room, teetering crazily, wearing CHARLOTTE'S JACKET, BACKPACK, and HAT. Everyone FLINCHES and SCREAMS. Amid a chorus of laughter, Charlotte enters. Grinning, she wags a facetious finger -- CHARLOTTE See? Surprises suck!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WILLS' BEDROOM -- NIGHT An antique clock ticks crisply on the dresser. Wills stands before a mahogany mirror, buttoning a freshly laundered white shirt. Lying on the cradle bed, half-wrapped in a sheet, naked but for a string of pearls, is TANYA, 35, raven-haired, much too thin. She smokes a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stretches with her cigarette but before she can make it to the ashtray, her ASH FALLS on a New York magazine. On the cover is a PHOTOGRAPH OF WILLS standing next to a YOUNG CHEF in a fashionable restaurant. The caption reads: "The Prodigal Son Returns."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He slips in a cuff link. She affects a breezy indifference -- TANYA Fine then. We'll go, I'll get big, fat, and horrible, and it'll serve you right. Wills slips on a silk tie -- WILLS No, it won't. Because it takes at least a few weeks to get fat and by then you won't even be speaking to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops tying his tie and stares at her in the mirror -- WILLS Because we have no future. All I can offer you is this... what we have right now... nothing more meaningful... until it ends. He goes back to tying his tie, then adds softly -- WILLS I could have waited to tell you, but I wanted to leave no room for misunderstanding. She stares at him, speechless.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Wills, please, not again. It's our third date and we're already in a rut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I thought you loved it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I do -- except for the fact that there isn't a single thing on the menu I can eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a chuckle) Sure, there is; there's just very little you're willing to digest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (curiously) Why do you say that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . RESTAURANT -- THAT NIGHT Its decor is exquisitely tasteful, its ambiance warm and convivial. The night is in full swing. Most of the tables are taken and the bar is packed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From amid the RUSH OF TRAFFIC, a TAXI breaks free and glides to the curb in front of the RESTAURANT. Its facade is windowless. Only a small brass plaque on the grey marble reveals that this is ELYSIUM. Wills and ERIKO, 30's, Japanese, aloof and stunning, emerge from the taxi, elegantly dressed, and move to the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pass Wills and Eriko as they enter. One recognizes Wills and smiles flirtatiously. Wills stops and helps Eriko off with her jacket. JESUS, 30, the dashing Cuban-American maitre d', superbly discreet, approaches -- JESUS Good evening, Mr. Keane. Will you be dining with us tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills hands Eriko's jacket to MELISSA, 20, the hat check girl -- WILLS How are you, Melissa?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We certainly will. Table seven, Jesus, if it's available.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blushing) Fine, Mr. Keane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: mid-20's, the chipper, blonde Midwestern hostess, arrives, wearing a stunned, glassy smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Celia, barely making eye contact with Eriko, walks quickly away. Wills is amused and a little confused by Celia's behavior. He lays a hand on Eriko's back -- WILLS I'll be right with you. Eriko nods and follows Celia. Wills moves to the reservation stand where his best friend and the restaurant's manager, JOHN VOLPE, 40, a brilliant, dapper, tough as nails Brooklynite stands, listening to someone on the telephone. Wills lays a hand on his shoulder and mutters into his ear -- WILLS How's it going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills laughs and takes a look into the bar. John gestures with his head in Eriko's direction -- JOHN So who's the new potential ex-wife? I thought you were still wastin' time with Tanya-von-What's-her-name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills exits into the bar. John smiles and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, Celia. And how -- CELIA (with forced cheeriness) Just dandy, sir, thanks!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Table seven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This way, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (covering the phone) Chaos.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The house specialty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy for you to say, ya prick. Waltzin' in here like you own the joint.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We wisely agreed to cut our losses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as he glides along the bar. CUSTOMERS and STAFF greet him warmly. As he enters the main dining room, DINERS spot him -- sprinkled among them are CELEBRITIES from every walk of city life. Wills greets them, stopping to shake their hands and kiss their cheeks. Suddenly, Celia, the hostess, red-faced, blocks his path -- CELIA Look, I have no right to say this, okay? And you can fire me if you want, but in the six weeks we've been open you've brought in six different women -- tonight makes seven -- and it's really starting to get to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shocked, she can't help but sputter a laugh -- CELIA It is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both laugh. He moves closer, lowers his voice, and speaks with warm sincerity -- WILLS Actually, I appreciate your concern, Celia. The truth is I'm a little worried myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills smiles, pats her in the shoulder, and moves on. She can't believe it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In what way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to greet them! It's like working at a dog shelter! I'm afraid to learn their names or even smile at them because I know any minute they could be put down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I assure you it's an absolutely painless procedure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. (beat) Especially for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seriously?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seriously. I've been trying to do better. (uneasily) But... you know how it is... old habits die hard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So I'm not fired?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope. In fact, John's been looking for an assistant. Tell him you've just been promoted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: carrying a BIRTHDAY CAKE -- blazing with candles and decorated with a WOMAN'S HAT made of MERINGUE LATTICEWORK -- passes by on his way to the REAR DINING ROOM. From inside, VOICES begin to sing HAPPY BIRTHDAY. Wills, his curiosity piqued, follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waiter sets down the cake at the center of a round table. There's a CHEER and APPLAUSE as the song ends. Wills cannot see whose birthday it is because the waiter blocks his view. Just as Wills is about to exit the room, the waiter steps away. Wills glances over and sees the birthday girl. At first he can't place her, but then he does, and his face softens and brightens. It's Charlotte. She wears a black velvet dress and a wonderfully eccentric hat. Her eyes glow in the candlelight. Through the chorus of voices, urging her to make a wish, she cries out -- CHARLOTTE You guys! Let me think! (concentrating) Okay. Okay. Charlotte blows hard, and, with a little more effort than you might expect, extinguishes the candles. Everyone APPLAUDS and CHEERS. To Charlotte's right sits SIMON LORING, late 20's, English, sardonic, adoring. He gestures at her CHEST and says -- SIMON Watch carefully, everyone -- they ought to begin emerging any moment now. Everyone laughs. Charlotte playfully slaps him -- CHARLOTTE Very funny! Actually, any moment now you're gonna turn straight and fall at my feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte's best friend, SHANNON HARRIS, 19, a spoiled but big-hearted redhead, drowning in curls, mutters -- SHANNON The only time he falls at your feet now is when he wants to borrow your Prada loafers. More laughter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, darling, you know I would if I could.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . He considers approaching Charlotte, but then he looks back and sees Eriko sitting alone at their table, idly stabbing at her drink with a straw. Regretting his rudeness, he takes a step toward her, but then hears -- WOMAN'S VOICE Is that Wills Keane? He turns and sees DOLORES TALBOT, 70, blonde wig, spindly frame, weathered skin, large, sad eyes. She holds a mixed drink -- WOMAN It sure as hell is and he hasn't changed a bit!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His smile shows uneasy surprise -- WILLS My God, it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he hugs Dolores, he can't help but look over at Charlotte again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, do I -- WOMAN You little fool, it's Dolores Talbot. Dolly!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I know, time's kicked my ass but good. Come on, Romeo, let's bury the hatchet. Give me a hug. Careful of the cocktail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what the hell're you doin' around here? Last I heard you were out in earthquake country blowin' the family fortune.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, I doubled it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good for you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . She looks over. Her view is such that she sees Wills but not Dolores. A faint blush creeps into Charlotte's cheeks. She pretends to listen as Shannon tells a story -- SHANNON -- and you know how bouncer's get. He's like, "That's the worst fake I.D. I've ever seen." And I'm like, "Yeah? Well, you have the worst dread- extensions!" And then just when -- Noticing Charlotte's distraction, Simon whispers calmly to her -- SIMON Are you feeling all right? You look positively green. Charlotte speaks under her breath without moving her lips -- CHARLOTTE He's here. And he's staring at me again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both Shannon and Simon turn to look, but like lightning Charlotte grabs them both -- CHARLOTTE Don't! (to Simon) Wait a few seconds, then go to the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte watches furtively as Simon rises from his chair and walks over. As he passes Wills, he flashes him a seductive smile. Wills is confused by it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shannon swivels her head and throws an aloof, vacant stare in Wills' direction. Then she looks back at Charlotte, mouth agape -- SHANNON He's as old as my dad! Charlotte laughs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No way!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How will I know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's beautiful. And much older.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? (getting up) If he's rich you might have a fight on your hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . He does his best to be attentive as Dolores exhales a plume of smoke into his face -- DOLLY Sure, L.A.'s okay if you're a cactus or a lizard, but if you're a New Englander, your soul dries up and blows away like a god damn leaf.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It only took me twenty years to come to my senses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what're you doin' now? You owned some restaurants out there, didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . She sits listening to Shannon -- SHANNON And so, after all that, we pay our cover, we get in, and it's totally heinous! Nothing but losers and -- Charlotte looks over and pales, her eyes widening -- CHARLOTTE Oh, shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolores walks up, hauling Wills by the arm -- DOLLY Kids! I want you to meet an old chum of mine, the owner of this fine establishment -- Wills Keane! The table greets him. Wills, slightly self-conscious, looks at everyone but Charlotte.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The news hits Wills hard. But he does his best to hide it. He musters a casual smile -- WILLS Not Katie and Jay's daughter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolores indicates the hat that Charlotte's wearing -- DOLLY Made it herself from scratch. That one, too. (to Shannon) Honey, show 'im. Shannon makes an elaborate comic show of modeling the hat she's wearing. The table laughs. Wills levels his gaze at Charlotte -- WILLS Impressive. Try as she might to accept the compliment with grace, Charlotte can't help but grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The WINE STEWARD stands at a station on which sit TWO BOTTLES OF CHAMPAGNE on ice. He reaches for one. Wills stops him -- WILLS I think we can do better than that. The steward, understanding, nods and departs, taking the champagne with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amused, he flashes Charlotte his most dazzling smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills turns to exit. Simon, returning to his seat, murmurs seductively to Wills as he passes by -- SIMON Leaving so soon? Wills looks at him, confused again, then continues on. As Simon sits, he mutters to Charlotte -- SIMON Be still my beating heart. (beat) Or is that your heart?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte turns to Dolores who has just sat down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolores eats a sloppy forkful of birthday cake.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that over there's the birthday girl -- my granddaughter, Charlotte.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You bet. She got her height from her dad. But her talent's all Katie's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Happy birthday, Charlotte.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (under her breath) Twenty years old and never been...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Shut up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll let you get back to your celebration. (kissing Dolly's cheek) A pleasure to see you again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Same here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whisper to Charlotte) You're not really into him, are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Dolly, how do you know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uneasily) From Newport. Old friend of your mom's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WINDOW -- ESTABLISHING -- MORNING A gentle breeze tickles a white lace curtain. A PHONE RINGS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte, standing in the small antiquated kitchen, wearing flannel pajamas, tenses when she hears the PHONE RINGING UPSTAIRS. She snatches an apple from a bowl and dashes out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: running through the DINING ROOM... into the LIVING ROOM... into the FOYER... and up a DARK STAIRCASE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHARLOTTE'S BEDROOM -- MORNING A startling clash of childhood, adolescence, and womanhood. Everything from stuffed animals to posters of pop icons to volumes of great literature.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte bangs in, flings herself on the bed, and grabs the phone -- CHARLOTTE Okay, bitch, I'm ready!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WILLS' ROOFTOP TERRACE -- MORNING Wills sits in his woolen robe, holding a portable phone. Amused, he smiles into the morning sun -- WILLS For what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her heart stops. She sits up slowly, her body tensed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my God, I'm so sorry! Wait. Who is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wills Keane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who did you think it was?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My friend Simon, actually. He always calls me the morning after to sort of... you know... sum everything up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And how would you sum it up, Charlotte? Turning twenty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kinda cool, kinda creepy. Anyway, you wanna speak to my grandmother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a chuckle) I don't think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: 30's, Wills' Jamaican cook and housekeeper, enters. Plump, handsome, and perpetually amused, she carries a tray laden with continental breakfast and a New York Times. Wills mouths a greeting. She smiles back and sets the tray on a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte runs over to her sewing table, looking for a pen and paper. She finds paper, but no pen -- WILLS Her dress is a sheath... sleeveless, black. The hat must, of course, be black or white or both. She finds a pen but it doesn't work. She grabs an eyeliner and uses that -- CHARLOTTE Any particular style?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His tone has abruptly shifted; it's intimately hushed. It both daunts and excites her -- CHARLOTTE Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She clicks off the phone, wilts into a swoon on the bed, and breaks out laughing. Wills, still holding the receiver, stares dreamily into the middle distance. He snaps to when Olivia enters. Her accent is as much Queens as it is Caribbean -- OLIVIA See, now you got me worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She throws him a sly, sidelong glance, then exits. Wills laughs and contentedly sips his coffee.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I called because I'm going to be attending a benefit... a black-and- white ball.... and I'd like you to design a hat... for my date.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? Wow. Sounds fun. Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a gift. I don't have her measurements, but she's about your size. What're you, a six?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good -- then let's assume your hat size is also the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But that doesn't necessarily -- WILLS It's a risk we'll just have to take.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sipping his coffee) No, just plenty of it. How long will it take?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A week or two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have till Thursday. I'll need it here by seven o'clock. I'm at the Pembroke on Central Park West and 76th.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Wow. Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's your fee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (faltering) I don't really have one. I usually just make them for friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's five hundred dollars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? Wow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlotte?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You say "wow" a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It has to stop. You're a woman now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You slept alone last night. You must be sick or somethin'. You want me to call a doctor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, no, I'm fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: we hear the sound of SQUEALING, LAUGHING, SHOUTING CHILDREN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FAO SCHWARZ -- NIGHT Surrounded by swarming PARENTS and KIDS, Wills stands with John, the manager of Elysium, and his wife, SARAH VOLPE, 30, who, gazing out of frame, keeps a watchful eye on their kids -- JOHN Save it, pal! Don't even bother! I may not have gone to a fancy school like Bendover -- WILLS (to Sarah) That would be Andover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills and Sarah meet eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sarah shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, if his folks could have afforded it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: but when Wills Keane comps three bottles of Dom to a twenty-year-old girl, then tells me he did it 'cause he likes the kid's grandma, I smell a rat!

direction.raw_text: R ON CHARLOTTE. She builds her hat on a HAT BLOCK -- a wooden mannequin head. Strewn all around her are the materials of her hatmaking -- bolts of cloth, hat blocks, a sewing table. Shannon, wearing sweats and a T-shirt, lies on the floor, eating M+M's and drinking diet soda, while heavily marking up a text book with a YELLOW HIGHLIGHTER. Charlotte stops and rubs her eyes, then she glances down at Shannon and smiles -- CHARLOTTE Why don't you mark what isn't important? That way you'll save ink.

direction.raw_text: She emerges, moves to Wills' door, and waits for the elevator to close. When it does, she hurries back to a table over which hangs a GILDED MIRROR. She takes a LOVELY OLD HAT BOX out of the garbage bag and ditches the bag under the table. Then she quickly checks herself in the glass. She doesn't like what she sees. She pokes at her sopping hair and squeezes it, but it's hopeless. Remembering the time, she hurries back to the door, takes a deep breath, and rings the bell. She waits. And waits. Then she hears footsteps approaching. She realizes she's left the hat box on the table. She rushes over and grabs it, just in time to get back to the door when it OPENS. Olivia, the housekeeper, steps out, wearing her coat and carrying her purse. Her voice is low and gentle -- OLIVIA He's waitin' for you, Miss Fieldin'. They exchange cordial smiles. Charlotte enters.

direction.raw_text: The room is vast, furnished with antiques, decorated with the same masculine good taste. Charlotte enters timidly, then hears -- WILLS What happened? She looks and sees Wills standing, back turned, before a broad set of high windows. City lights glimmer in the distance; beneath them lies the vast gloom of Central Park.

direction.raw_text: Wills turns around. A magnificent figure -- expertly tailored tux, every hair in place, freshly manicured. And then he offers her an amused, reassuring smile -- WILLS Charlotte, relax. What's the point of being a beautiful young woman if it isn't to keep your admirers waiting? In fact, you disappoint me: I was looking forward to at least another half hour of suspense. Flattered, her face brightens -- CHARLOTTE I could leave and come back.

direction.raw_text: He walks over to her. Smiling, she sets down the box, unties the ribbon, and gingerly removes the hat. It's sublimely simple and elegant. She looks at him with hope. His face betrays nothing -- WILLS Try it on.

Wills appears behind her and shares the reflection. She feels his presence, hears his breathing. They speak in hushed tones -- WILLS It's perfect. It's like a tiny sculpture.

direction.raw_text: She smiles. Their eyes meet in the glass.

She taught me how to cook and sew... speak Italian... basically enjoy life, have fun -- that's what she was best at... even when she knew she was dying. (pause) The most important thing she did was introduce me to poetry. She believed it was the highest form of art and that everything we say and do should aspire to it. direction.raw_text: Wills laughs, then opens the bottle as he picks up his previous train of thought -- WILLS You see, Charlotte, the way you know you're getting older is that you start to notice patterns. People start falling into types. Pretty soon you know a person before you've even been introduced. And if it's a woman, before the romance even starts, a whisper in your head tells you exactly what it is and how long it's going to last. And the saddest, the most tedious, part of all is that that little voice is almost always right. (popping the cork) Now, what I like about you -- and I think that's actually what inspired this little lecture -- is that I find you completely unprecedented... and, therefore, wholly unpredictable.

She does not kiss back. Finally, he pulls away, staring blankly, breathing hard, not sure what to say. Charlotte whispers -- CHARLOTTE See? You're a typical. (pause) And for what you just did, most girls my age would slap your face. Or ask to be put in a cab. (pause) Lucky for you, I'm a unique. She smiles, then kisses him deeply on the mouth. Her arms wrap around his neck.

PAUL SIBLEY, 60, African-American, dour and forbidding, enters -- SIBLEY Mr. Keane? Dr. Sibley. Wills jerks to his feet and they shake hands -- WILLS Thank you so much for taking the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks around the desk. Sibley is all business, but his brusqueness masks genuine regret -- SIBLEY Now, Mr. Keane, on the phone you referred to Charlotte's condition as cancer. That isn't strictly accurate. Neuroblastoma is a soft tissue malignancy, but it isn't cancer -- although it sometimes can be just as aggressive. (sitting) It's most common in children. In young adults, the condition is extremely rare. In Charlotte's case, the tumor is located in her chest. It's growing rapidly and has proved resistant to both irradiation and chemotherapy. And because of its proximity to her aorta, surgery is out of the question.

direction.raw_text: Wills shifts uneasily in his chair.

direction.raw_text: A silence settles between them. Sibley opens a folder on his desk.

direction.raw_text: . TAXI -- AFTERNOON As the cab bounces down a cobblestone Village street, Wills and Charlotte stare straight ahead, each following the tortuous path of his own thoughts. Slowly, Charlotte steals a sidelong look at him. His face is tense, ashen, and unreadable -- CHARLOTTE Hey. Wills slowly turns his head. She smiles sweetly -- CHARLOTTE Look on the bright side: if I weren't sick, there's no way we could hang out together. (off his look) I'm serious. You'd be scared of hurting me and I'd be scared you were just using me for my perfect young body. He can't help but smile. Encouraged, she moves closer -- CHARLOTTE And then our friends would say we were just into each other for weird psychological reasons. You know, because I'm looking for a daddy substitute and you're looking for someone you can feel superior to so you won't have to confront how scared you are of real intimacy -- and, of course, they'd be right and eventually we'd break up. (beat) But since I'm so sick it doesn't really matter what deep-seated weirdness has brought us together because there's no way we can possibly screw each other over... or up... because that takes time. And I don't have much left. The cab comes to a stop in front of her brownstone. She smiles archly, savoring the irony -- CHARLOTTE So considering everything, don't you think we should just sort of chill out, forget I'm sick, and enjoy what we have... right now... no strings... just this... until it ends? 'Cause that's really all I have to offer. Wills grimly appreciates the irony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses his cheek and jumps out of the cab. She skips up the steps of the brownstone, then immediately turns around and runs back down to the open window. She leans in and mutters sexily -- CHARLOTTE Last night was so incredibly hot. (beat) By the way -- it was my first time. And I picked you for the job. I hope you're flattered. Wills is shocked. She turns and runs back upstairs. She sticks in the key, then turns and waves at Wills before banging open the door with her hip.

direction.raw_text: Wills hasn't moved a muscle.

Illuminated in flashes, the driver's eyes have taken on an ominous, unblinking quality as though they were the outward embodiment of his own conscience. Wills looks out the window. When he finally speaks, his voice is calm and a little cold -- WILLS Look, I never pretended to be anything other than -- CHARLOTTE (a piteous cry) You hate yourself so much! Wills is stunned. He walks back in and sets them into the shopping bag. He looks around and spots a nearly completed crossword puzzle sitting folded on the dresser. He drops that in the shopping bag, too, then sets it by the door. He feels a draft and spots an OPEN WINDOW. As he crosses to it, he notices something on his pillow. A blank ENVELOPE. He picks it up and rips it open. It's a HALLOWEEN CARD of a grinning JACK-O-LANTERN. He opens it and inside is handwritten: The scariest night of the year and only one thing haunts me: that we might never have met. All my love, XXX Charlotte. Wills lowers the card and heaves a deep breath. His jaw tight, he walks over and drops the card into the shopping bag.

direction.raw_text: He stops and leans back against a building. He looks around, avoiding eye contact with John, as tears rise into his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills is still unable to look at him. John speaks softly -- JOHN Buddy, I hate to break it to you, but in the real world... where I live... there're only two kindsa love stories. Boy loses girl and girl loses boy. That's all there is. Somebody always gets left behind. You try to avoid that, you'll end up an old man toastin' yourself with egg nog in the mirror on Christmas Eve. You'll end up dying in your own arms. Wills lifts his frightened eyes. John pats him on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (with disgust) What the hell is that? Some sorta shrink talk?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, if she were just fun... just some sort of diversion... maybe I could justify it. But the worst part is that it's becoming more. Much more. It's embarrassing how much I like her. She gets to me. She affects me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And she's gonna be gone and... I'm not sure I can... I mean... I already think about her all the time... (fighting tears) Her smile kills me... and the thought... that it'll be gone... forever... that I'll never see her again... I don't know... I can't -- I don't think I'm that strong, Johnny. It's too much. I'd rather have it be over... over now. I'll start missing her now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HIGH-RISE APARTMENT BUILDING -- NIGHT Wills stands with Patty in the driveway in front of the glass lobby. He is distracted and terribly anxious. She looks as though she expects, at the very least, a kiss -- PATTY Thank you so much. I had such a great time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Relieved to have unburdened himself of the truth, he shakes her hand. Patty, utterly baffled, doesn't know what hit her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good. I'm... I'm glad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Patty, I... I want to be honest with you... right now, from the start... so there's no room for misunderstanding. I didn't have a good time, but it's nothing personal. I just split up with someone and rather than admit to myself how much I miss her, I asked you out instead. And it's unfair. If I feel sad I should just feel sad and not try to use you... and your body... as some sort of painkiller, right? (beat) Anyway, I think you're a warm and engaging woman and I wish you all the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WILLS' BUILDING -- LATER The doorman Michael, smoking a cigarette, sees Wills walk up, his expression pensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills stops and turns -- WILLS Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He winks. Wills realizes that it's Charlotte. It must be. He smiles and hurries inside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Keane -- WILLS Good night, Michael.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got a visitor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's been waitin' almost an hour. In the lobby. (off Wills' look) A little surprise for ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wills bursts in and freezes. A WOMAN stands across the way, studying an oil painting. She turns quickly. It's LISA. She sees his excited expression fall. Beneath her rather composed facade, Lisa is a chaos of conflicting emotions -- LISA Sorry to disappoint you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An awkward silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His sincerity stops her. She softens slightly, mustering a tiny smile -- LISA Thanks. Anyway, I guess it made me want to meet you. I've been a little sentimental about parent-hood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills chuckles. For the first time, Lisa relaxes enough to take him in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa smiles, and, much to her embarrassment, tears come to her eyes. She shakes her head at how absurd she is, treasuring kind words from a father she doesn't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sniffles and looks away -- LISA Nothing earth-shattering. Maybe just to hear you say you were sorry. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stares at him long and hard, waiting for some more palpable sign of remorse. It isn't forthcoming. Finally, she nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and walks away. His voice stops her -- WILLS Can I call you? She turns around, hesitates for a moment, then nods. She continues to the door. But then she stops and turns -- LISA Before... when you came in... who did you think I was?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles simply and heads for the door. When she is gone, Wells slowly walks back toward the elevators, but then abruptly stops in his tracks, deliberating...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, no. Not at all. You surprised me, that's all. I didn't expect to see you... not here... not after your letter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I didn't expect you to show up at my job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I followed you in. I wasn't even sure it was you. All I have is an old snapshot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My boss thought you were a stalker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't mean to run off like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you got my letter. What'd you do? Freak out? Burn it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saved it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was just blowing off some steam, okay? I think I have the right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So do I. Look, why don't we go upstairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uneasily) No. I didn't plan to come. Peter... my husband... he agrees. He thinks it's a futile exercise. But it turns out I'm pregnant. Just a few months, but -- WILLS Lisa -- Congratulations. That's wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that what you consider me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In a lousy absentee sorta way, sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's your mom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great. Nuts. She moved to Costa Rica last summer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A guy, what else? He owns a charter airline and wears sunglasses indoors. I think he might be a gunrunner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, you're much better looking in person than in photographs. I always assumed Mom was exaggerating, but she wasn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. You're not bad looking yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway... I should go...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Already?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I really just wanted to meet you and... maybe... I don't know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) What is it? Tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am. I'm very sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must like her an awful lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . VILLAGE -- DAWN THE CAMERA CRANES DOWN SLOWLY from a view of the sun rising in the EASTERN SKY to a TAXI gliding over to the curb in front of...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte, looking tired and a little pale, pays the driver and emerges from the taxi. She makes her way up the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking down from the second-floor landing, we see Charlotte enter and walk up the stairs toward us. As she reaches the landing, she feels a STABBING PAIN IN HER CHEST and stops walking. Wincing, she waits for the pain to subside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte enters wearily, drops her purse on the floor, then turns and GASPS. Wills lies sprawled in an armchair fully dressed, sound asleep. Charlotte is offended by the intrusion. She hurries over to awaken him. But then she stops. Her face softens slightly. She studies his face... touches his cheek with the back of her hand... traces the lines at his eyes with a fingertip.. smooths back a wisp of hair. Finally, snapping to, steeling herself, she jostles him -- CHARLOTTE Hey. Wills wakes with a violent start. When he sees her, he drops his head back. He closes his eyes again and murmurs sleepily -- WILLS Where were you? I was worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She crosses coldly to her closet and, half-shutting the door, blocking his view, starts to undress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits up, rubbing his eyes in the morning light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills sits forward, more alert now. He exhales heavily and begins:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and looks at him. She feels herself relenting. She turns away and continues undressing -- CHARLOTTE Why should I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops, then glances at him with a flash of pain and longing. Determined not to surrender to her feelings, she crosses to the bed and throws open the covers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She crawls into bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills, relieved, crosses to the bed and begins to undress. He asks casually -- WILLS So where were you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thinking nothing of it, Wills nods. He slips into bed. Her back is to him. He drapes an arm around her and pulls her a little closer. He smiles contentedly and closes his eyes. But then something occurs to him. He opens his eyes -- WILLS Hung out where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He closes his eyes again. A few beats later, they open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte, eyes still closed, breaks into a sly, amused smile.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So worried you fell asleep. What're you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've missed you. You have no idea how much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How'd you get in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dolly. We watched TV. She fell asleep. What time is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't know I had a curfew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where were you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: None of your business. So what is it? What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To tell you that you were right. I do hate myself. But not so much that I can't see how stupid and despicable and -- CHARLOTTE Cowardly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And cowardly what I did was. And even though there's no excuse for it, I want you to forgive me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because, for better or worse, I'm falling in love with you, and the thought of our not being together is unbearable to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the morning, we'll talk about what a gigantic asshole you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With Shannon and Simon and Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's Eric?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An old friend who used to work at Blockbuster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd you guys do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Talked and drank. Simon and Shannon finally went home. Eric and I hung out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop. We'll talk about it tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Talk about what? Is there something to talk about? What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CENTRAL PARK WEST -- DAY Wills and Charlotte, collars turned up against the brisk wind, walk together. Charlotte wears a backpack. Wills tries desperately to appear casual -- WILLS No, honestly, I think I have a right to know.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And I honestly think I have a right not to tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're being unreasonable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're being nosy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CENTRAL PARK -- DAY They move down a winding walkway beneath barren trees -- WILLS You know, in this day and age it's not so outrageous a request. I mean, I don't know this kid. I don't know where he's been.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing incredulously) You're worried about where he's been? Give me a break!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WOLLMAN RINK -- DAY Wills watches as Charlotte laces up her figure skates -- WILLS It requires balance and I have lousy balance, okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She burst out laughing -- CHARLOTTE Not even close!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, come on, what's the worst that can happen? (beat) Well, I guess you could break a hip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I'm not in a sporting mood!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How come?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm jealous, okay?! Is that what you want to hear? Are you satisfied now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WOLLMAN RINK -- DAY Wills paces the bleachers, furious, while Charlotte skates nearby -- WILLS All I want is a simple answer and you're torturing me! And I resent it! It's cruel and juvenile! And I -- CHARLOTTE (exploding)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her anger startles him. She skates over quickly and skids to an abrupt stop -- CHARLOTTE It's not! It's adult! It's revenge! And if you think it's bad not knowing what I did -- well, it's even worse knowing exactly what you did! She turns and skates away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WOLLMAN RINK -- AFTERNOON Wills sits on the bleachers, miserably brooding, while Charlotte gracefully glides by, laughing and chatting with THREE YOUNG MALE SKATERS whom she's just met.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk together in silence. Wills is sullen. Finally, Charlotte takes his hand and speaks gently but firmly -- CHARLOTTE Do me a favor, okay? Never ask me again what happened with Eric. Just accept the fact that you'll never, ever know. And if that hurts, then think about it next time you want to cheat on somebody. Wills reflects.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WILLS' BEDROOM -- NIGHT Charlotte and Wills are little more than silhouettes, lying entwined in the rich darkness, conversing in whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte laughs. Wills smiles with sad irony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He thinks for a moment, then smiles, and kisses her brow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wish I were exaggerating, but I'm not. I slept with every one of them. Really. Look through Dolly's old photo albums... or any movie magazine... visit Aspen at Christmas. I was on a mission. And until recently I really didn't think I had a problem. Or if I did, it was definitely the most pleasurable one I could imagine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What changed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My house in Malibu burned to the ground.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, it sounds funny. But it must have triggered something because the next thing I knew I couldn't sleep. I'd lie awake at night absolutely terrified. Like a kid left alone in the dark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What were you scared of?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How quickly time was passing and how adolescent I still felt. How meaningless all my choices seemed. How lonely I was. So I liquidated my portfolio, sold my businesses, and moved back here. To start over, settle down, start acting my age. (beat) You were supposed to be my one last dalliance with youth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, for your sake, I hope I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MACDONALD'S -- DAY Wills sits with John, Sarah, and the twins at a plastic table overrun with food, wrappers, and squashed condiment tubes. Sarah speaks to Wills -- SARAH Judge you? Why would I? Screw the age difference -- I like the new you! Before Charlotte came along, do you have any idea how hard it was to get you to sit down for a Happy Meal? Wills and John laugh. Molly, one of the twins, chimes in -- MOLLY Uncle Wills, how come you don't get married?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills gives both of the little girls hugs and kisses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills shakes his head and smiles, reluctant to answer. From the next scene we hear the sound of TWO DOZEN PEOPLE BREATHING FURIOUSLY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, how come, Uncle Wills?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to, Carla, but -- MOLLY I'm not Carla! I'm Molly!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Molly, I just haven't met the right woman yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about Charlotte? She's funny- pretty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (aside to Wills) It means funny and pretty. It's their highest compliment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I agree. (rising from the table) She's also demanding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where're you goin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's decided she wants her birthday present today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But that was last month.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Dom didn't count. This is her real present. She chose it herself and it's not material.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you got me curious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, what is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . STUDIO -- AFTERNOON On a slightly elevated stage, HARI SINGH, 35, an American Sikh wearing a white robe and turban, sits in the lotus position before a lighted candle, softly instructing the crowded class -- HARI Okay... breath of fire... now inhale deeply... hold the breath... let your heart lotus blossom... feel the energy rise... and exhale. Good. Now peacock pose. Hari rolls forward, digs his elbows into his midsection, and pops up so that he is parallel to the floor with his legs still crossed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: all moving into the pose. In the center of the class are Wills and Charlotte, wearing sweats. His arms shaking, Wills is clearly in pain. He mutters -- WILLS When does the enlightenment start?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills laughs. A moment later, Charlotte winces and falls out of the pose onto the mat. Hari looks over, confused -- HARI Are you all right? Charlotte sits up quickly, smiling -- CHARLOTTE Yeah. No big deal. Cramp in the old fifth shakra! She glances over at Wills. He sees that she's scared to death. He helps her to her feet, speaking softly in her ear -- WILLS Don't worry. You're gonna be okay. She nods. They move toward the door. But after a few steps, her eyes flutter, her body goes limp, and she slams down on the mat, UNCONSCIOUS.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When you realize that I'm God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SPEEDING AMBULANCE -- AFTERNOON Charlotte lies on a stretcher near Wills and a PARAMEDIC -- CHARLOTTE It's no big deal. I just hyperventilated. Really. But then she gasps as she's hit by a stab of pain. Wills throws a grave look at the medic and squeezes her hand more tightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VINCENT'S HOSPITAL -- ESTABLISHING -- NIGHT The building is brightly illuminated against the night sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VINCENT'S WAITING ROOM -- NIGHT Wills sits, anxiously struggling with a half-finished crossword puzzle. He hears the click of a lighter. A GRUBBY LITTLE MAN standing by the coffee machine lights a generic cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills looks up and sees Dr. Sibley standing in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me... do you have an extra one of those?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eyes narrowing) You a smoker?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not for years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, hell, if I'm gonna be the one to get you goin' again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't mention it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . TELEMETRY FLOOR CORRIDOR -- NIGHT Sibley walks Wills down the hallway -- SIBLEY The repeat MRI and CAT scan do show interval progression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They arrive at Charlotte's room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (uncertainly) Which means the tumor's grown?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Yes, it has. Considerably. As for her loss of consciousness, one explanation is a disturbance in her heart's electrical function. We'll be monitoring her overnight for any arrhythmias. If we find something, we'll treat it. Unfortunately, the more likely explanation is that the tumor has begun to obstruct the outflow of her heart. If that's the case, there's little we can do. We could be speaking in terms of weeks not months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When she returns home, we'll want her to stay active, but don't let her overexert herself. (off Wills' nod) Don't stay long. She's been sedated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Charlotte lies in the bed with her eyes closed. An EKG monitor bleeps steadily in the corner. An IV drip hangs by her bed. Wills enters and sits down at her bedside. He touches her hand. She opens her eyes and smiles drowsily -- CHARLOTTE Hey. Wills is terribly anxious. His speech is accelerated
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods and inhales deeply. His heart is racing. She murmurs -- CHARLOTTE You still owe me a birthday present.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles sleepily. Wills lifts a hand to her mouth and whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her eyes drift shut -- CHARLOTTE I am so pretentious... Wills laughs, then clears his throat, and looks suddenly serious -- WILLS Charlotte, listen, I -- CHARLOTTE Uh-oh. Heavy, heavy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He considers for a moment, then, tears welling in his eyes, he lifts her hand to his mouth and kisses it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you all right? You're okay? How do you feel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stoned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll let you rest. I should. You'll sleep and then -- CHARLOTTE (touching his hand) Shhh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just 'cause I fainted is no excuse for you to bail on your peacock pose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It ought to be illegal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your smile. It's too pretty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've ruined you for other women.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All part of my master plan. (beat) Do you wanna hear a story... a bedtime story?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shouldn't I be telling you one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Once upon a time, there was a woman on a ship crossing the Atlantic and her little boy got sick. Very sick. And she said whoever saves my boy's life... I'll name my next baby after them. Well, they got into port and they rushed her son to St. Vincent's hospital... to here... and they saved his life. And so the mother named her next baby Edna St. Vincent Millay. (beat) And Edna grew up to be, as I am sure you know, the second greatest female poet in American history.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The first would be Emily Dickinson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a quick learner -- I like that about you... (half to herself) "It may be, when my heart is dull, Having attained its girth, I shall not find so beautiful The meagre shapes of earth, Nor linger in the rain to mark The small of tansy through the dark."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just think -- CHARLOTTE No. No violins. I'm fine. Go home... sleep...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BROWNSTONE LIVING ROOM -- AFTERNOON Wills sits across from Simon who strokes Shannon's back as she weeps -- SHANNON It just didn't seem real and now that it is, I hate it! It's so unfair! Dolores, sitting in her armchair, mutters as though by rote -- DOLLY Fare is what you pay on the train to Jersey. Fair is the place that smells like manure where, if you're real lucky, you win a blue ribbon for your home-made pickles. Fair is a sky without a cloud and a face with a mark. Fare is food. What fair isn't is everything else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dolores chuckles. Simon continues to Wills -- SIMON Now, correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe what you're saying is that while the end may be in sight, it has not yet arrived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills falters, looking at him incredulously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills stares at Simon, his face ashen and full of contempt -- WILLS Tell me, are you really so cold? Or is it just a pose that you've cultivated?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shannon looks at Simon and burst into tears again. Simon holds her even closer, rubbing her back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I think I speak for all of us when I say that we've heard quite enough from Dolores.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. The tumor's begun to interfere with the function of her heart, but she -- SIMON Then why exactly have you called us here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I cut short a lunch date, Shannon's missing her low-impact aerobics class, and Dolores has delayed the start of her happy hour -- surely you must have had good reason.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought Charlotte's health might be of some interest you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is. You could have told me all about it on the telephone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I also thought it might be a good idea if we discussed ways to make her as comfortable as possible for the -- SIMON Charlotte loathes comfortable. I never sought to bore her with comfort while she was well, why should I start now that she's sick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a pose that I've cultivated. (beat) I chose it, as a sort of smoke screen, some time after attending my twentieth funeral in as many months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's quite all right. But, honestly, it shocks me how often you people forget. Our phone books have as many numbers crossed out as written in. So that while death is certainly as painful to us as it is to you, we do not find it nearly so... extraordinary. (beat) Don't misunderstand me. I adore Charlotte and when she dies, I would... were it not already in that state... cry my heart dry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wills emerges from Charlotte's brownstone, hails a cab, then decides against it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Head down, eyes desolate, Wills walks uptown. The roaring traffic, dense crowds, blaring music, flashing neon -- the great welter of urban life is entirely lost on him. He can think only of Charlotte.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HELL'S KITCHEN -- NIGHT Wills walks down a dark block, his jacket open to the cold night wind, his cheeks and ears burned red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HELL'S KITCHEN WALK-UP FOYER -- NIGHT Wills enters, checks the tenant list, then presses a buzzer. He speaks into the intercom and a moment later is buzzed up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: running up the stairs. He arrives at a door, cold and gasping for breath. He hears footsteps.

direction.raw_text: but we do not see who is there.

direction.raw_text: . WALK-UP LIVING ROOM -- LATER Wills paces, speaking desperately to someone. He seems on the verge of a total nervous collapse -- WILLS She's in the hospital now. She doesn't have long. Weeks maybe and -- She... Anyway, I have something to ask you. A favor. I have no right to ask. I know. I'd do it myself, but I can't. I'm too... I'm... He takes a deep breath to keep himself from crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: his daughter, sitting on the couch, listening, her face unreadable -- LISA What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills, stunned, deeply grateful, allows himself a breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa, flooded with compassion, wants to go to him, comfort him, but she stays where she is.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to find a surgeon. Dr. Sibley told me... Charlotte's doctor told me... he said at some point, when it's hopeless, surgery could be an option. Heroic surgery, he called it. I want to make sure that when the time comes a hero is performing that heroic surgery. Do you understand? You'll have to make calls. I'll get names. Sibley will give me names. (fighting tears) I'm sorry to ask you... I have no right. But, you see, she doesn't want it... this surgery... I'll have to convince her. So no one can know... for now. And I trust you. You're my only family and I... (beat) You have every right to refuse me. After what I did. You were a child... and you needed me... and I was nowhere to be found. There's no excuse for that. I'm so terribly sorry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd be happy to do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dad, I'm really sorry she's sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost inaudible) I am, too. So sorry. I should be the one. It should be me.

direction.raw_text: . CARL SCHURZ PARK -- LATE AFTERNOON The darkening sky is swept with a brisk wintry breeze. Shadows descend from the trees and towering rocks. AN OLD MAN sits on a bench, reading a newspaper. A NANNY pushes a baby carriage past. Wills and Charlotte walk together, bundled up again the cold. Charlotte walks backward, her breath shooting out into the cold air like smoke -- CHARLOTTE You never talk about my mother. (beat) Talk about her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte smiles happily.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want to know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everything. All I remember is that she smelled like vanilla, loved to read to me, and was really good at cutting up fruit. I couldn't believe she didn't cut her fingers off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I remember a little more than that. Let's see... she was blonde... about your height -- CHARLOTTE I've seen pictures, dummy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, okay. She... always ate her ice cream with a fork -- how's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Much better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And she wrote great letters, but couldn't spell at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Neither can I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was a McGovern Democrat but also an incredible snob. She loved blueberries. She had the world's worst backhand. Her favorite singer was Stephen Stills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind. She was afraid of sharks. And, considering the times, she was pretty square. She only tried drugs once -- a lifeguard gave her a hash brownie and she threw it up all over him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And she laughed just like that. And she bit her fingernails. And she couldn't tell a joke. (beat) In short, she was a unique.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . EAST RIVER ESPLANADE -- MINUTES LATER Wills and Charlotte lean down on the railing, watching the water purl and eddy around Randall's Island.

direction.raw_text: Wills looks at her darkly. She smiles and shrugs -- CHARLOTTE It's just a question. Wills sighs and looks away, reflecting -- WILLS I have no idea. The summer was over. Your mom was going back to Smith. I was moving down here to work on Wall Street. It was our last day together. She was crying. She told me, for the first time, that she loved me. I said I loved her, too. I promised to call and visit. A few hours later I was in a cabana with Millie. (beat) When Millie told me she was pregnant and that she wanted to marry me, I escaped to L.A... and I never saw her or your mom again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She considers for a moment -- CHARLOTTE But I want everything from you, Wills. I rely on you in every way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him and smiles. He puts an arm around her and draws her close.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you know she was in love with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She told me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were you in love with her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? Because she was the only girl in Rhode Island who wouldn't sleep with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's how she got my attention; it's not why I fell in love with her. (beat) I fell in love with her because she charmed me senseless day and night for an entire summer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why did you screw her best friend on Labor Day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wryly) Well done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think it's part of the reason I never came back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But why're you like that? What is it? I mean, you weren't born that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I might as well have been. For as long as I can remember, I've always run off at the first sign of a woman wanting anything from me... relying on me in any way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So the only reason you don't dump me is because I'm sick? Because you know that it's all going to be over, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe. But it doesn't feel that way. (beat) It feels as though I'm not afraid anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . TAXI -- AFTERNOON Wills looks out the window, his arm draped around Charlotte who lies nestled against him, eyes closed. He suddenly sees something. He thinks. Checks his watch. His eyes ignite and he calls out excitedly to the driver -- WILLS Driver! Quick! Pull over here! Right here! Charlotte, a little sleepy, comes to. She looks out the window and her face softens with happiness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the steps of the old church a CHOIR sings Christmas carols. All around them, a LARGE CROWD sings along. Wills and Charlotte get out of the cab. His arm around her, Wills pulls her into the crowd. They join the carol. Wills sings well. Charlotte is tone deaf. In between lines of the song, she calls out -- CHARLOTTE I didn't know you could sing!

direction.raw_text: She laughs and continues to sing.

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't know you couldn't!

direction.raw_text: to cheers and applause. THE CHOIRMASTER steps forward to a microphone -- CHOIRMASTER Well, you all know what time it is!

direction.raw_text: He grins. The choirmaster nods at someone in the distance. Then holds up a hand, fingers spread, and begins to count down. The crowd joins in -- CHOIRMASTER AND CROWD TEN, NINE, EIGHT, SEVEN, SIX, FIVE, FOUR, THREE, TWO, ONE! At that instant, ALL THE WHITE CHRISTMAS LIGHTS on the trees of the median from 96th Street to 44th Street POP ON SIMULTANEOUSLY -- an enchanted fairy-tale spectacle. The crowd and the choir cheer and clap, cars honk their horns. Charlotte's eyes are filled with happy wonder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As another carol begins, Wills wraps his arms around Charlotte and kisses her. He pulls away, looks deeply into her eyes, and whispers with passionate sincerity -- WILLS I love you, Charlotte. For an instant, her eyes flare as though she were surprised. Then her eyes fill with tears. She tries to speak but she is choked by a sob. She buries her face in his chest and cries. Wills smiles with warm, almost paternal, indulgence. He strokes her hair. She hugs him as though she'll never let go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wills listens to Dr. Grandy who speaks casually, more like a benign hippie than a renowned surgeon. Charlotte's X-rays hang between them in an illuminated view box -- GRANDY Listen, I'm not gonna bullshit you. If she were a baby, she'd have a decent chance, 'cause these sorts of tumors can regress like crazy, but she's twenty and... I don't know, man... I've never seen anything like it. (pointing at the X- ray) I mean, look! It's wrapped around her vital structures like an octopus! (sitting) You know, just once I'd like to get sent something simple. A "cabbage," a valve replacement. Even a good old- fashioned transplant. But it doesn't happen anymore. It's the downside of being good at my job.

direction.raw_text: . WILLS' BEDROOM -- MORNING Charlotte lies asleep with her head on his chest. She opens her eyes. The room seems strange. It's the light. She rises up and turns around. Her eyes narrow with curiosity. She crawls out of bed and runs to the window and looks out. She can't believe her eyes. Central Park is blanketed by deep snow and more is falling. She calls out gaily -- CHARLOTTE Hey! How do you feel about Christmas?

direction.raw_text: She runs back, laughing, and jumps on the bed, rousting him.

direction.raw_text: showing Charlotte and Wills during a day of holiday shopping. The deep snow has slowed the city to a crawl but filled everyone with good spirits. Charlotte and Wills move from store to store; they buy wreaths, garlands, ornaments, candles, and, finally, a CHRISTMAS TREE and STAND. Wills starts to lug the tree, but when it's obvious that it's too much for him, Charlotte spots a GROUP OF KIDS spilling out of a record store. The next thing we know the kids are lined up, carrying the tree over their heads like a battalion of ants. Wills and the kids load the tree into the freight elevator and squeeze in. There's no room for Charlotte. She'll take the lobby elevator.

direction.raw_text: Wills stares at her for a moment, then explains without apology -- WILLS I met with a heart specialist. He's willing to operate. dialogue.raw_text: Straight?

dialogue.raw_text: Of course not, but if you'll hear me out -- CHARLOTTE No! I told you right from the start how I felt and you went behind my back! You lied and -- WILLS (exploding) Oh, Christ, knock it off! You're such a god damn saint, so above it all, but you're scared to death! You do want to live! And if you were as honest as you say you are you'd let the doctors do whatever they can to help you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?! Maybe we want hope! Or maybe we just need to know that we did everything we could! Maybe I need to know that... if I'm going to be able to live... to go on without... without --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now I know why you hurt so many women. Because you always knew if you held on to one of them, you'd never let go.

direction.raw_text: . WILLS' BEDROOM -- LATER In grey afternoon shadows, Charlotte lies on her side, fully clothed under the covers, with her eyes open, thinking. She hears something and looks back. Wills stands in the lighted doorway. She gestures for him to come. He walks over and lies down next to her. She turns her back to him, so that he's spooning her, but she takes hold of his hand, pressing it against her chest and squeezing it like a doll. For a long time, they lie in silence. Finally, she murmurs almost inaudibly -- CHARLOTTE When we met, I was so lonely. But I didn't even know it. I'd been alone so long.. almost forever...

direction.raw_text: Fighting his emotions, determined to stay strong for her, he holds her close.

dialogue.raw_text: I'll do whatever I have to! I'll tear up the papers! Whatever you want! Tell the doctor! Because... I really do want... I don't want to leave you!
